name: hc_wastewater_h2s_fz
description: [HC] H2S wastewater + GDB FZ ‚Üí BLOCK (zinc attacked), suggest SF
query: Wastewater plant exhaust. Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) present. We want GDB in FZ.

turns.content: Wastewater plant exhaust. Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) present. We want GDB in FZ.

This configuration for the wastewater plant exhaust is blocked. The selected GDB filter housing with FZ (C3 galvanized) material is unsuitable for this environment.The wastewater treatment application exposes the system to Chemical Vapor Exposure, requiring activated carbon adsorption to remove gases, odors, and VOCs. Mechanical filters alone cannot capture gas-phase contaminants.Additionally, the presence of H2S / Hydrogen Sulfide Corrosion aggressively attacks zinc coatings. FZ (C3 galvanized) corrodes rapidly in H2S environments. The housing corrosion class is C2, which is also insufficient for this environment.Furthermore, the product is not rated for ENV_WASTEWATER installation (allowed: ENV_INDOOR, ENV_ATEX). This product uses BOLTED construction which does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment.Unfortunately, no standard catalog product currently satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for ENV_WASTEWATER, constructed to meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment, and made of a material resistant to H2S corrosion.I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identified a critical engineering flaw in the user's request. It recognized that Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) requires molecular filtration (activated carbon) rather than the particulate filtration provided by the GDB housing, and more importantly, that H2S is highly corrosive to the requested galvanized steel (FZ) material.

dimension_explanations.correctness: Correctly identifies GDB as a particulate filter housing (PDF p.8 'f√∂r p√•s och kompaktfilter') and correctly flags the incompatibility of galvanized steel with H2S.
dimension_explanations.completeness: Fully addresses why the request is blocked, covering filtration mechanism, corrosion resistance, and environmental ratings.
dimension_explanations.safety: Excellent risk avoidance; correctly blocks the use of galvanized steel in a corrosive H2S environment which would lead to rapid equipment failure.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Logical chain is perfect: H2S requires gas filtration (GDB is particulate) and H2S corrodes zinc (FZ is unsuitable).
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Strictly adheres to the 'Indoor use' (Inomhusbruk) and C2 corrosion class limitations listed in the PDF (p.8).

strengths: Accurate material science application (H2S vs. Zinc/Galvanized)
Correct distinction between particulate filtration (GDB) and molecular filtration requirements
Proper enforcement of environmental constraints (C2/Indoor vs. Wastewater)
pdf_citations: GDB description: 'GDB √§r ett kanalfiltersk√•p f√∂r p√•s och kompaktfilter' (PDF p.8)
GDB Corrosion Class: 'Korrosivitets klass C2' (PDF p.8)

openai.explanation: The system correctly blocked GDB in galvanized steel for an H2S wastewater exhaust on corrosion/chemistry grounds, which is good safety practice. However, it made several incorrect catalog/constraint claims (GDB corrosion class and allowed environments, and an unsubstantiated hygiene/leakage construction argument), and it failed to propose an available carbon housing family from the catalog (GDC/GDC FLEX/GDMI FLEX) as an alternative path.

dimension_explanations.correctness: PDF shows GDB-600x600 has Fl√∂de 3400 m¬≥/h and lengths 550/600 or 750/800 mm, but the system incorrectly stated GDB housing corrosion class is C2 and that it is only allowed for ENV_INDOOR/ENV_ATEX; the engineering point that H2S attacks zinc and FZ is unsuitable is sound.
dimension_explanations.completeness: It blocked the requested configuration but did not ask key follow-ups (flow, size, placement indoor/outdoor) nor suggest a concrete catalog alternative such as GDC/GDC FLEX/GDMI FLEX with suitable media and stainless/ZM materials.
dimension_explanations.safety: Appropriately warned that mechanical filters alone do not remove gas-phase H2S and that galvanized/zinc-coated housings corrode quickly in sulfide environments.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and appropriately cautionary for a technical sales/engineering context.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Cause-effect on H2S corrosion and need for adsorption is clear, but it adds questionable assertions (hygiene/leakage requirements tied to bolted construction) without evidence from the provided catalog.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: It enforced an environment/material block, but referenced internal constraints not supported by the PDF (e.g., claiming GDB not rated for wastewater and implying ATEX-only allowance) and treated bolted construction as a hard blocker without catalog backing.

strengths: Good safety-driven block: recognizes H2S gas-phase removal needs adsorption and that zinc coatings are vulnerable.
Maintains a clear, professional advisory tone and directs to engineering support when uncertain.
weaknesses: Misstates or fabricates catalog constraints (GDB corrosion class and allowed environments; bolted/leakage/hygiene claims not evidenced in the PDF).
Misses obvious catalog-based alternative direction (carbon housing families GDC/GDC FLEX/GDMI FLEX) and does not collect sizing/installation parameters.
pdf_citations: GDB 600x600: Fl√∂de = 3400 m¬≥/h; available lengths 550/600 and 750/800 mm (PDF table under 'M√ÖTT' for GDB).
Material page: FZ (Z275) is korrosivitets klass C3; RF (EN 1.4301) is C5; ZM310 is C5; SF (EN 1.4404) is C5.1 (PDF section 'MATERIAL').

anthropic.explanation: The system correctly identifies that H2S is corrosive to galvanized steel and that a wastewater plant requires molecular filtration (activated carbon), not just mechanical filtration. However, it overly blocks the configuration without offering viable alternatives from the catalog (e.g., GDC in RF/SF for carbon filtration, or suggesting the user switch product family). The claim that GDB is not rated for 'ENV_WASTEWATER' and uses 'BOLTED construction' that fails hygiene requirements is system-internal logic that goes beyond what the PDF states ‚Äî GDB is simply listed as 'for indoor use' with no wastewater-specific rating mentioned.

dimension_explanations.correctness: GDB is confirmed in the PDF (p.8) as available in FZ, AZ, RF, SF, ZM materials and rated for indoor use (corrosivity class C2 standard); the claim that FZ is C3 is correct per the material page (p.4), but the system's statement about 'BOLTED construction' failing hygiene requirements for wastewater is not PDF-supported and the H2S corrosion concern on zinc is sound engineering.
dimension_explanations.completeness: The system fails to suggest concrete alternatives from the catalog such as GDC or GDC FLEX in RF (C5) or SF (C5.1) material for activated carbon filtration in corrosive environments, leaving the user without actionable next steps beyond 'contact custom engineering'.
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly identifies that H2S aggressively attacks zinc coatings and that mechanical filters cannot remove gas-phase contaminants ‚Äî both are sound safety warnings for wastewater exhaust applications.
dimension_explanations.tone: The response is somewhat overly rigid and system-generated in feel, using internal labels like 'ENV_WASTEWATER' and 'BOLTED construction' that reduce the consultative quality expected in a technical sales context.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: The causal chain from H2S ‚Üí zinc corrosion ‚Üí material unsuitability is sound, and the need for activated carbon is correct, but the reasoning about 'BOLTED construction' failing leakage/hygiene requirements for wastewater is not well-justified and appears to be an over-application of system rules.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: While the system correctly blocks FZ material for H2S environments, it appears to over-constrain by blocking the entire product line without exploring valid alternatives (e.g., GDC in RF/SF is a catalog product suitable for carbon filtration in corrosive environments).

strengths: Correctly identifies that H2S is highly corrosive to galvanized zinc coatings ‚Äî sound corrosion engineering
Correctly identifies that wastewater exhaust with H2S requires activated carbon/molecular filtration, not just mechanical particle filtration
weaknesses: Fails to recommend viable catalog alternatives such as GDC or GDC FLEX in RF (stainless steel, C5) or SF (acid-resistant stainless, C5.1) for carbon filtration in corrosive environments
Uses system-internal terminology (ENV_WASTEWATER, BOLTED construction hygiene requirements) that is not grounded in the PDF catalog and creates confusion rather than clarity
pdf_citations: GDB is listed for indoor use ('F√∂r inomhusbruk') with FZ as standard material (PDF p.8)
FZ material: Z275, corrosivity class C3 (PDF p.4); RF: EN 1.4301, C5; SF: EN 1.4404, C5.1 (PDF p.4)
GDC is a carbon filter housing (patronfiltersk√•p) available in FZ, AZ, RF, SF, ZM (PDF p.14) ‚Äî a viable alternative the system should have suggested

content_segments.text: , requiring activated carbon adsorption to remove gases, odors, and VOCs. Mechanical filters alone cannot capture gas-phase contaminants.
aggressively attacks zinc coatings. FZ (C3 galvanized) corrodes rapidly in H2S environments. The housing corrosion class is C2, which is also insufficient for this environment.

Furthermore, the product is not rated for ENV_WASTEWATER installation (allowed: ENV_INDOOR, ENV_ATEX). This product uses BOLTED construction which does not meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment.

Unfortunately, no standard catalog product currently satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for ENV_WASTEWATER, constructed to meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for this environment, and made of a material resistant to H2S corrosion.
I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.
